comments.text:

{See Nylon-eating bacteria}

In case you haven't heard, scientists have also discovered bacteria that

Consider the hypothetical scenario in which the global environment would

bacteria that would be the sole survivors

This is, yet, one more explanation that falsifies theory of evolution. 
Since, according to the postulations of the theory, bacteria, being single 
cell organisms, should possess the least degree of survivability. While the 
greater the degree of complexity possessed by multicellular organisms, the 
greater the degree of survivability that they would also possess

Bacteria are the "KINGS OF SURVIVAL"... due to the fact that, amongst other

& asphalt

All the while, continuing to exist as single celled bacteria... due to the

...Each must come forth after their own kind
comments.author: Chuichupachichi

comments.text:
+Cameron Seebach
 {You seem to be denying the evolution of new species}

This statement is one which cannot be responded to with the simplicity of 
either yes or no. That's due to the fact that a problem is caused by the 
word "species". In fact, within Biology, it's referred to as the "species 
problem"

Notice, I said that humans can't give birth to anything other than humans 
and the example I used for animals was that canines can't give birth to 
anything other than canines.

Nevertheless, a variety of different canines can be, and have been, 
descended from a particularly specific canine. All canines have descended 
from Canis Lupus (Wolf). This is simply the result of micro evolution, 
i.e., variation...which does occur. Therefor, considering that Taxonomy 
categorizes Wolf, Coyote, Fox, Dingo etc. as each one a distinct species, 
then my response is, no, I don't deny the (micro) evolution of new species.

However, evolutionists claim that "speciation" occurs, with the implication 
being that it proves macro evolution. Thus, whenever the word "species" is 
used in this manner, then my response is, yes, I do deny the evolution of 
new species

But my two different responses to the same word is not causing the problem. 
But rather, evolutionists are causing the problem by using the word 
species, while remaining oblivious to the "species problem"

This is what you need to know...evolutionists explain that whenever a 
population of organisms separate from a greater population, biological 
changes may occur while living in a different environment. Thus, if members 
of the break away population attempt to interbreed with members of the 
original, parent population, they'll be incapable, due to the biological 
changes. Or if they can successfully interbreed, but cannot produce viable 
offspring, then it is said, from either scenario, that "speciation" has 
occurred

This is the explanation of "speciation" and the same explanation is 
presented as the standardized definition of the word "species". However, 
the problem is that there exist animals, such as, various species of 
canines that can interbreed and produce viable offspring. Also, every 
example presented by evolutionists as the occurrence of speciation, is 
merely another occurrence of variation. The Salamanders are still 
Salamanders etc. etc. etc.

The fact is that the validity of "speciation" is completely dependent upon 
the existence of a standardized definition of the word "species". No such 
definition exists and within the scientific field of Biology, this is known 
as the "species problem"
comments.author: Chuichupachichi

comments.text:
+Cameron Seebach
{but don't difficult circumstances, like those facing "modern" societies 
throughout time, cause evolution to work in the favor of intelligence?}

The theory of evolution itself, doesn't claim to work in the favor of 
anything. It postulates that after a number of random mutations have become 
part of a greater population, a particular mutational morphologic change 
may enable its recipient organism to survive a new, hostile environment 
that has killed the entire rest of the population

The fact is, mutations are reproductive defects. Thus, they are not better 
suited, than are correctly reproduced organisms, for overcoming life 
threatening, biological adversities. Mutations are, themselves, a 
biological adversity

This is why, for as long as man has been observing mutants within nature, 
every time its been observed that they're the first to die. They don't 
survive even ideal environmental conditions...much less, conditions hostile 
to their species

Listen, everyone on Earth knows that there doesn't exist even one human 
that can give birth to something other than a human. Every reproductive 
human can give birth to only another human and nothing else. It's a hard 
rule of Biology & it cannot be broken. Biologists know in detail, the 
specific reasons why reproductive systems are subject to this hard rule

Therefor now, consider a pair of human mates that reproduce, They, being 
humans, are subject to this hard rule of Biology. Thus, they necessarily 
give birth to a human. That offspring, being human, is also subject to the 
same, unbreakable, hard rule of Biology. Thus, he necessarily reproduces 
another human offspring. Now we're up to the third generation and the same 
hard rule applies to him because of his humanity

You can continue that reproductive line for thousands or millions of years 
and the results will never change because the cycle is one of continual 
self perpetuation. This unbreakable, hard rule of Biology continually 
perpetuates itself upon every generation, causing the neverending 
perpetuation of only human offspring

This reproductive hard rule applies, not only to humans, but also, to all 
other biological organisms. Canines cannot give birth to something other 
than Canines...etc. etc etc.

Thus, we find, scientifically, that each must come forth after their own 
kind

comments.text:
+FlawlessCock
I wouldn't call myself a genius (although I have been objectively told that 
people see me as a genius). Heck, I can't remember the last time I took an 
IQ test.

Speaking of which, don't even bother taking those free online IQ tests. 
They're too easy to manipulate into giving you a higher score than if you 
were to sit down with an official test from a panel of reputable 
psychologists.

Back on subject.

Reading does help to expand your vocabulary and force you to be creative in 
imagining the story or information forming in your mind's eye. I did read a 
lot (in fact, I was reading and memorizing whole children's books when I 
was only 3 years old), and I still do just to keep my imagination sharp, 
and I do so whenever I get the chance to.

If there is anything I am a genius at, it is at music, piano-playing, and 
storytelling.

And you could probably become a genius at understanding and contributing to 
the field of studying psychopaths and sociopaths. You just have to keep 
applying yourself.

To me, the best indicator of genius in a person is that they are committed 
to learning something so much, no matter how daunting it gets, that they 
eventually excel at it. To put it in perspective, it takes an average of 
10,000 hours to achieve expertise in any given field of study, even 
physical fields like gymnastics and martial arts (speaking of which, I'm a 
Black Belt in Shotokan karate and am currently teaching myself Chinese 
martial arts).

Don't let others' achievements be a reflection of your current status. You 
stay committed to what you want to excel at (or become a genius at), and 
most likely, you will become one in due time.

Keep up the hard work and study. ^_^
comments.author: mikecucuk

comments.text:
+mikecucuk
I had to look up "apply yourself". It basically means to work hard at 
something you are interested in. Well I do have an interest in psychopaths, 
how they function and how to defend against them. Robert Hare is an 
excellent author of the subject. I'm also interested in psychology, I'm 
more interested in the how rather then why. The cause/effect of the human 
mind. More then that I don't know.

Are you a genius? Do you have a high IQ? Did you read a lot?

yours answers are much appreciated :)
comments.author: FlawlessCock

comments.text:
+FlawlessCock
Don't put up barriers to your success.

Even if you don't get up to a 200 adult IQ score, so what?

Contrary to popular belief, you don’t have to have a special “math brain” 
to be able to understand the Pythagorean Theorem.

And you don’t have to be good at English to be able to write a decent 
analysis of Arthur Miller's *Death of a Salesman*.

You just have to learn how to do it, work hard, and apply yourself.

Actually, it's doubtful that Einstein even said that. Quote Investigator 
shows that the tree-and-fish quote emerged gradually from an allegory about 
the nature of education, finally resulting in the internet-friendly text in 
question which was then attributed to Einstein (perhaps because people 
think “Einstein” when they think “genius”?)

In fact, later in life, Einstein said this:

"“There are only a few enlightened people with a lucid mind and style and 
with good taste within a century. What has been preserved of their work 
belongs among the most precious possessions of mankind.”

Now, what would you do to become one of those few enlightened people? Are 
you willing to learn, work hard, and apply yourself? I have, and it has 
taken me to many different places of thought and imagination that I have 
never known before.

Trust me. You'll find something that you can excel at. Just keep applying 
yourself. ^_^
comments.author: mikecucuk

comments.text:

comments.author: FlawlessCock

comments.text:
+FlawlessCock
While increasing your IQ is certainly possible on a test, be careful. 
Knowledge and ability are two different things when it comes to measuring 
one's intelligence.

And there is also the question of achievement in relation to IQ. For 
instance, you probably never heard of Abdesselam Jelloul (who scored 198 on 
an adult IQ test), but you certainly heard of Albert Einstein (who would 
only score 145 on the same test today).

Bottom line: your achievements will always stand out more than an IQ score. 
Go for the 200 score if that's what you desire. Just be sure to put your 
intelligence to use beyond a test and contribute back to the world.
comments.author: mikecucuk

comments.text:
+FlawlessCock
I would suggest doing lateral thinking puzzles.

As for reading, I would suggest academic journals on subjects that interest 
you and novels of science fiction and classic literature.

Oh, and if you haven't already, take up an instrument to play.

All these have really helped me become more intelligent. Maybe it will help 
you, too, if you're really that concerned about improving your current 
mental status.

I don't know if they will necessarily increase your IQ, but remember that 
IQ is simply a measure of mental potential. It isn't a guarantee for future 
application, let alone success.

There's no substitute for applying yourself and taking initiative, so hit 
the books and discover your untapped potential. ^_^

comments.text:
+UrintheTwilightZone It did. I don't know what to say. I have never heard 
of research that demonstrates how shorter scenes affect attention and the 
reward system so I cannot really say anything about these claims of yours. 
I might be interested in reading about that because I study psychology. 

If I were to explain these phenomena, I'd say that it is (from my 
experience) very common for people to enjoy the original, first parts of 
almost anything. People have this conservative attitude towards the things 
they enjoy. Most people enjoy ''the first movie'' or ''the first season'' 
or ''the first album'', and it is not, at least for me, rare to encounter 
this kind of thinking. Are you sure that's not the case for you as well?

It is true that The Big Bang Theory started off as less dramatic/emotional 
and was more of a comedy, but the same happened with friends, and many 
other series. It's because the producers usually don't want shows to get 
stuck and repeat an endless looping plot. Friends is a good example of a 
series where the story begins with less drama but as the show goes on, the 
emotional aspect of the show deepens. 

Whether a given show is good sounds like a matter of an opinion to me, not 
brainwashing. I don't watch TV almost at all, but I do like some series 
like House, Lie To Me, Criminal Minds and yes, The Big Bang Theory. Still, 
I would not say that I like these shows because the scenes are shorter...
comments.author: Ontern

comments.text:
+Revealer
I wasn't insulting viewers of the big bang theory in particular.

I was simply referring to the fact that scenes in TV (and in movies) have 
gotten shorter. Which have reduced people's attention spans, as well as 
made the content more addictive.

I believe the average scene shot on TV used to be about 8 seconds.
it's been reduced to about 2 seconds, so basically every couple of seconds 
you're being barraged by content, which cannot be good for the mind.
(I'm going off of memory so those might not be exact figures, but they're 
close approximations, feel free to look it up.)

As for intellectually stimulating content, I do listen to TED talks on 
occasion, as well as Joe Rogan, and Alan Watts. as well as many others.

With all that said, I feel as if you may have taken my comment the wrong 
way and I hope my elaboration of what I meant cleared some of that up.

Good Day to you.

comments.text:
+JJ, if we may be so informal.
'Odds' are predictable, which implies a range of possible values, as in 
life, and in fact, the universe. There is no 'perfection' in the universe. 
Concepts such as the 'set of integers' are merely practical methods of 
limiting the complexities of our existence. They don't in fact exist. 
Concepts of thought such as ideologies, love, hate, independence, freedom, 
etc. give us a sense of understanding without the burden of proof and so 
rely on our shared faith.
Ultimately all of these concepts are simply chemically induced structural 
patterns in the brain. The fact that we seem to share these concepts is 
less the proof that they are somehow self-evident, concrete facts and more 
likely the result of the common physiological structure of our brains 
manipulated by the common reactions of our senses to similar environmental 
factors. Different environments have obviously resulted in very different 
environmental factors that contributed to actual physiological differences 
between our races.
Commonly shared factors of thought and behavior, such as ideologies and 
cultures are what you might call 'higher' functions because they seem more 
sophisticated than those of what we consider more 'primitive' creatures. 
They are intellectual constructs developed over a millennia of 
trial-and-error struggles to survive and reproduce, which is nothing more 
than you'd expect from the simplest of creatures.
In a very real sense we have 'gone over-board' by continuing to put our 
survival above the survival of any other species; we've forgotten how we 
got here. Our most significant threat is now ourselves and our unbridled 
fear and obsession to survive well beyond our needs. There's actually a 
minority of humanity that we all have to worry about, the affluent, the 
religious and to some extent, the intellectual (including the 'super 
genious').
These Republitards, as I call them, whether they are money grubbing 
a-holes, religious fanatics or simply the lower-intellect minions who long 
for a better life and are fooled by the false profits of the latter two 
groups into believing that if those groups succeed than their lives will 
somehow become better as well, are the true bane of man's survival. You 
appear to be part of the minion, and as such, you are useless to this or 
any other discussion related to the superiority of man, his genius or his 
survival, and you will never 'see' the truth.
comments.author: Brian Tumor

comments.text:
'Guided objects' implies a 'force' of some type. Presently science only 
recognizes 4 primary forces that 'control' all 'reactions' from the 
molecular level up to the intergalactic. Any other 'force', be it 
spiritual, godly or dumb luck, is based purely on 'faith'. Ergo, you have 
as much chance of faith-based forces, or a 'Maker', controlling the 
particles within you as are demonstrated by flipping a coin, the act of 
which itself can be nearly completely (99%) described in terms of the 4 
scientifically prescribed forces. Where our scientific explanation fails, 
or rather, where the 1% is unexplainable, is a subject of what happens in 
our minds when we focus our attention on the process of flipping the coin. 
In other words, it's purely psychological. If that is where you choose to 
dwell, in the murky depths of the subconscious, then you are no longer 
interpreting life scientifically, or even practically, but in the same way 
that a primitive being of little scientific understanding would dwell, and 
your 'faith' is simply your ignorance.

captions.text:
If you watch the Big Bang Theory on CBS television
you see these clueless nerds who are doormats

when ti comes to the opposite sex, right.
And you realize is there any basis in reality?

First of all none of my friends are like that
and all my friends are physicists, right.

Well there is a kernel of truth and that is
some of these individuals may suffer from

something called Asperger's Syndrome which
is a mild form of autism. These people are

clueless when it comes to social interactions.
They don't look you in the eye, for example.

And yet they have fantastic mental and mathematical
capabilities.

We think, for example, that Isaac Newton had
Asperger's. The greatest scientist of all

time was very strange. He had no friends to
speak of. He could not carry a decent conversation

and yet here he was spitting out some of the
greatest theories in the history of science.

Calculus. The Universal Law of Gravitation.
The Theory of Optics. And we think he had

Asperger's Syndrome. Now Asperger's Syndrome
is a mild form of autism and in autism we

have what are called savants. That is people
that have an IQ of maybe 80 but have incredible

mathematical and musical abilities. In fact,
some of these individuals can hear one symphony
and just play it by memory on a piano.

Other people could be in a helicopter, have
a helicopter ride over Manhattan, see the

entire New York harbor and then from memory
sketch the entire harbor. In fact, if you

want to see it go to JFK Airport in New York
City and you will see it as you enter the
international terminal.

So what is it about these people? Well, first
of all a lot of them had injuries to the left

temporal lobe. One individual had a bullet
as a child go right through the left temporal

lobe. Another person dived into a swimming
pool and injured very badly the left temporal

lobe. And these people wound up with incredible
mathematical abilities as a consequence.

And so what is it about their brains? Well
Einstein's brain has actually been preserved.

Einstein when he died had an autopsy in which
case the pathologist stole the brain without

permission of the family. He just realized
that he was sitting next to something historic,

took the brain, took it home with him and
it was sitting in a jar in his home for decades.

He even drove across the country with the
jar inside his trunk.

And there's even a TV special where you can
actually see the cut up brain of Albert Einstein.

And you realize first of all the brain is
a little bit different. You can't tell by

looking at it that it's so remarkably different
but you realize that the connections between

the prefontal cortex and the parietal lobe
-- a connection that is accentuated in people

that do abstract reasoning is thickened. So
there definitely is a difference in the brain

of Einstein. But the question is did it make
Einstein or did Einstein make this change

of the brain? Are champions born or are they
made? That still is not known because people

who exercise mental abilities, mathematical
abilities, they can thicken that part of the
brain themselves.

So we know that people who do well in mathematics
brain scans clearly show that their brains

are slightly different from the average brain.
So in conclusion, we're still children with

regards to understanding how this process
takes place. Tonight don't go home and bang

yourself on the left temporal lobe. We don't
know how it works. We just know that in a

tiny fraction of these cases people with injury
to the left temporal lobe, some of the become
super geniuses.
